objdescid.compdate: c. 1807 The poems themselves may have been composed as early as 1800-1804. Not earlier than 1802, and probably after the abandonment of the quarto *Ballads* project in 1805, Blake reutilized paper that had been used in William Hayley's Designs to a Series of Ballads, 1802 (to which Blake had contributed engraved illustrations), trimmed off Hayley's printed texts (and 1802 watermark), and on the spacious inside margins wrote out the poems. Three of the poems, "Mary," "The Grey Monk," and "The Golden Net," seem to be copied from drafts of 1803.

objinfo.note: The manuscript is in black ink, with the exception of corrections in possibly brown or grey ink. Faint offsets (ink transfers that occur over time when one written page faces another) appear throughout the manuscript.
objinfo.support: laid paperSee note on composition date, above.
objinfo.watermark: noneSee note on composition date, above.
objinfo.binding: cream rag paper with red leather spine Once stitched through three holes, probably in a dark olive-tinted cover, the manuscript was rebound in 1866 by "BY F. BEDFORD / FOR B. M. PICKERING" in red morocco with "BLAKE'S / POEMS / MS." on the spine. When bound for Pickering in 1866, the manuscript's edges were trimmed and gilt trimmed, affecting the tops of a few letters on Objects 17 and 18. It has since been rebound in cream rag paper with red leather spine.
objinfo.stabholes: three holes, 3.9 cm from the top and 4.5 to 4.6 cm apart

provenance.name: Morgan Library and Museum
provenance.note: Catherine Blake, probably by inheritance at William Blake's death in 1827; Frederick Tatham by inheritance in 1831; the dealer Francis Harvey, who offered the manuscript in his catalogue of c. 1864 (£15.15s); Samuel Prince, sold from his collection, Sotheby's 11 December 1865, lot 83 (£7.5s to Basil Montagu Pickering); William Mitchell, who added his bookplate; Frederick Locker-Lampson by 1876; E. Dwight Church, who sold the manuscript in 1905 through Dodd, Mead, & Co. to William A. White; the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach by 1929; Mrs. Landon K. Thorne no earlier than 1939; given by Mrs. Thorne to the Pierpont Morgan Library (now the Morgan Library and Museum) in 1971.

repository.department: Pierpont Morgan Library Dept. of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

desc.objtitle: The Smile, The Golden Net, Object 1 (Bentley 126.1)

objnote.p: A draft of "The Golden Net" appears in Blake's Notebook, page 14 (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 1302n).

lg.l: The Smile
There is a Smile of Love
And there is a Smile of Deceit
And there is a Smile of Smiles
In which these two Smiles meet
And there is a fFrown of HateErdman (page 482) does not note this emendation.
And there is a Frown of Disdain
And there is a Frown of Frowns
Which you strive to forget in vain
For it sticks in the Hearts deep Core
And it sticks in the deep Back bone
And no Smile that ever was smildsmiled
But only one Smile alone
That betwixt the Cradle & Grave
It only once SmildSmiled can be
But when it once is SmildSmiled
Theres an end to all Misery
The Golden Net
Three Virgins at the break of day
Whither young Man whither away
Alas for woe! alas for woe!
They cry & and tears for ever flow
The one was ClothdClothed in flames of fire
The other ClothdClothed in iron wire
The other ClothdClothed in tears & sighs
DazlingDazzling bright before my EyesBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1733n) suggests that "eyes" was mended to "Eyes".
They bore a Net of Golden Twine Erdman (page 483) and Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1303) read "Twine" as "twine".
To hang upon the Branches fine
Pitying I wept to see the woe
That Love & Beauty undergo
To be consumdconsumed in burning Fires
And in ungratified Desires
And in tears clothdclothed Night & day
Melted all my Soul away
When they saw my Tears a Smile
That did Heaven itself beguile
Bore the Golden Net aloft
As on downy Pinions soft
Over the Morning of my Day
Underneath the Net I stray
Now intreatingentreating Burning Fire
Now intreatingentreating Iron Wire
Now intreatingentreating Tears & Sighs
O when will the morning rise
The Mental TravellerTraveler
I traveldtraveledtravelled thro' a Land of Men
A Land of Men & Women too
And heard & saw such dreadful things
As cold Earth wanderers never knew
For there the Babe is born in joy
That was begotten in dire woe
Just as we Reap in joy the fruitBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1733n) suggests that "reap" was mended to "Reap".
Which we in bitter tears did Sow
And if the Babe is born a Boy
He's given to a Woman Old
Who nails him down upon a rock
Catches his Shrieks in Cups of gold
She binds iron thorns around his head
She pierces both his hands & feet
She cuts his heart out at his side
To make it feel both cold & heat
Her fingers number every Nerve
Just as a Miser counts his gold
She lives upon his shrieks & cries
And She grows young as he grows old
4 Till he becomes a bleeding youth
And She becomes a Virgin bright Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1304) reads "She" as "she".
Then he rends up his Manacles
And binds her down for his delight
He plants himself in all her Nerves
Just as a Husbandman his mould
And She becomes his dwelling place
And Garden fruitful Seventy fold
An aged Shadow soon he fades
WandringWandering round an Earthly Cot
Full filled all with gems & gold
Which he by industry had got
And these are the gems of the Human Soul
The rubies & pearls of a lovesick eye
The countless gold of the akeing achingheart
The martyrs groan & the lovers sigh
They are his meat they are his drink
He feeds the Beggar & the Poor
And the way faring TravellerTraveler
For ever open is his door
His grief is their eternal joy
They make the roofs & walls to ring
Till from the fire on the hearth
A little Female Babe does spring
And she is all of solid Fire 5
And gems & gold that none his hand
Dares to stretch to touch her Baby form
Or wrap her in his swaddling-band
But She comes to the Man she loves
If young or old or rich or poor
They soon drive out the aged Host
A Beggar at anothers door
He wanders weeping far away
UntillUntil some other take him in
Oft blind & age-bent sore distrestdistressed
UntillUntil he can a Maiden win
And to allay his freezing Age
The Poor Man takes her in his arms
The Cottage fades before his sight Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1305) and Erdman (page 485) read "sight" as "Sight".
The Garden & its lovlylovely Charms Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1305) and Erdman (page 485) read "lovly" as "lovely".
The Guests are scatterdscattered thro' the land
For the Eye altering alters all
The Senses will themselves in fear
And the flat Earth becomes a Ball
The stars sun moon all shrink away Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1305) and Erdman (page 485) read "stars sun moon" as "Stars Sun Moon".
A desartdesert vast without a bound
And nothing left to eat or drink
And a dark desartdesert all around
6 The honey of her Infant lips
The bread & wine of her sweet smile
The wild game of her roving Eye
Does him to Infancy beguile
For as he eats & drinks he grows
Younger & younger every day
And on the desartdesert wild they both
Wander in terror & dismay
Like the wild Stag she flees away
Her fear plants many a thicket wild
While he pursues her night & day
By various arts of Love beguildbeguiled
By various arts of Love & Hate
Till the wide desartdesert planted oerover
With Labyrinths of wayward Love

subst.add: Where roams the Lion Wolf & Boar

l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1306n) notes that the line is written over an erasure which may have begun with "They". Erdman (page 859n) notes the erasure without a reading.

lg.l: Till be becomes a wayward Babe Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1306) and Erdman (page 859n) both offer "weeping" as an uncertain reading of the illegible deletion.
And she a weeping Woman Old Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1306) and Erdman (page 859n) both offer "becomes a" as an uncertain reading of the illegible deletion.
Then many a Lover wanders here
The Sun & Stars are nearer rolldrolled

subst.add: The trees bring forth sweet ExtacyEcstasy
To all who in the desartdesert roam

lg.l: Till many a City there is BuiltBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1306n) notes that the erasure at the beginning of this line may have been "Built".
And many a pleasant Shepherds home
But when they find the frowning Babe 7
Terror strikes thro the region wide
They cry the Babe the Babe is Born
And flee away on Every sideBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1733n) and Erdman (page 859n) suggest that "Every" was mended from "every".
For who dare touch the frowning form
His arm is witherdwithered to its root
Lions Bears Wolves all howling flee Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1307) and Erdman (page 486) read "Bears" as "Boars".
And every Tree does shed its fruit
And none can touch that frowning form
Except it be a Woman Old
She nails him down upon the Rock
And all is done as I have told
The Land of Dreams
Awake awake my little Boy
Thou wast thy Mothers only joy
Why dost thou weep in thy gentle sleep Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 130) reads "sleep" as "Sleep".
Awake thy Father does thee keep
O what Land is the Land of Dreams
What are its Mountains & what are its Streams
O Father I saw my Mother there
Among the Lillies by waters fair
Among the Lambs clothed in white
She walkdwalked with her Thomas in sweet delight

objnote.p: Lines related to "Mary" appear in a letter to Thomas Butts, 16 August 1803 (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 1308n).

lg.l: 8 I wept for joy like a dove I mourn
O when shall I again return Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1307) reads "shall" as "Shall".
Dear Child I also by pleasant streams Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1307) and Erdman (page 486) read "streams" as "Streams".
Have wanderdwandered all Night in the Land of Dreams
But tho calm & warm the waters wide
I could not get to the other side
Father O Father what do we here
In this Land of unbelief & fear
The Land of Dreams is better far
Above the light of the Morning Star
Mary
Sweet Mary the first time she ever was there
Came into the Ball room among the FairBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1733n) suggests that "fair" was mended to "Fair".
The young Men & Maidens around her throng
And these are the words upon every tongue
An Angel is here from the heavenly climes Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1308) and Erdman (page 487) read "climes" as "Climes".
Or again does return the gGolden times
Her eyes outshine every brilliant ray
She opens her lips tis the Month of May
Mary moves in soft beauty & conscious delight The alteration in "Mary" is noted by neither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1308) nor Erdman (page 859n).
To augment with sweet smiles all the joys of the Night
Nor once blushes to own to the rest of the Fair
That sweet Love & Beauty are worthy our care
In the Morning the Villagers rose with delight 9
And repeated with pleasure the joys of the night
And Mary arose among Friends to be free
But no Friend from henceforward thou Mary shalt see
Some said she was proud some calldcalled her a whore Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1308) reads "she" as "She".
And Some when she passed by shut to the door Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1308) and Erdman (page 487) read "Some" as "some".
A damp cold came oerover her blushes all fled
Her lillies & roses are blighted & shed
O why was I born with a different Face
Why was I not born like this eEnvious rRace Erdman (page 459n) notes the alteration in "Envious", but not "Race".
Why did Heaven adorn me with bountiful hand
And then set me down in an envious Land
To be weak as a Lamb & smooth as a dove
And not to raise Envy is calldcalled Christian Love
But if you raise Envy your Merits to blame
For planting such spite in the weak & the tame
I will humble my Beauty I will not dress fine
I will keep from the Ball & my Eyes shall not shine
And if any Girls Lover forsakes her for me
I'll refuse him my hand & from Envy be free Erdman (page 859n) suggests an alteration from "Envy is free" to "Envy be free".
She went out in Morning attirdattired plain & neat
Proud Marys gone Mad said the Child in the Street
She went out in Morning in plain neat attire
And came home in Evening bespatterdbespattered with mireBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1733n) suggests that "evening" was mended to "Evening".
10 She trembled & wept sitting on the Bed side
She forgot it was Night & she trembled & cried
She forgot it was Night she forgot it was Morn
Her soft Memory imprinted with Faces of Scorn
With Faces of Scorn & with Eyes of disdain
Like foul Fiends inhabiting Marys mild Brain
She remembers no Face like the Human Divine
All Faces have Envy sweet Mary but thine
And thine is a Face of sweet Love in Despair Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1309) reads "Despair" as "despair".
And thine is a Face of mild sorrow & care
And thine is a Face of wild terror & fear
That shall never be quiet till laid on its bier
The Crystal Cabinet
The Maiden caught me in the Wild
Where I was dancing merrily
She put me into her Cabinet
And LockdLocked me up with a golden Key
This Cabinet is formdformed of Gold
And Pearl & Crystal shining bright
And within it opens into a World

And a littlelovely Moony Night The "e" at the end of "little" appears slightly smeared, possibly due to the erasure of "lovely". Erdman (page 860n) notes that "lovely" is written over an erasure; Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1309n) suggests that the deleted word may have started with "fl".
Another England there I saw
Another London with its Tower
Another Thames & other Hills
And another pleasant Surrey Bower
Another Maiden like herself
Translucent lovely shining clear
Threefold each in the other closdclosed
O what a pleasant termbling fear
O what a smile a threefold Smile
FilldFilled me that like a flame I burndburned
I bent to Kiss the lovely Maid
And found a Threefold Kiss returndreturned
I strove to siezeseize the inmost Form
With ardor fierce & hands of flame
But burst the Crystal Cabinet
And like a Weeping Babe became
A weeping Babe upon the wild
And Weeping Woman pale reclindreclined
And in the outward air again Erdman (page 489) reads "air" as "Air".
I filldfilled with woes the passing Wind

objnote.p: Lines related to "The Grey Monk" appear in Blake's Notebook and in "To the Deists", Plate 52 in Jerusalem The Emanation of The Giant Albion (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 1310n).

lg.l: The Grey Monk
I die I die the Mother said
My Children die for lack of Bread
What more has the merciless Tyrant said
The Monk sat down on the Stony Bed
The blood red ran from the Grey Monks side
His hands & feet were wounded wide
His Body bent his arms & knees
Like to the roots of ancient trees
His eye was dry no tear could flow
A hollow groan first spoke his woe
He trembled & shudderdshuddered upon the Bed
At length with a feeble cry he said
When God commanded this hand to write
In the studious hours of deep midnight Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1311) reads "studious" as "Studious".
He told me the writing I wrote should prove
The Bane of all that in Earth I lovdloved
My Brother starvdstarved between two Walls
His Childrens Cry my Soul appalls
I mockdmocked at the wrack & griding chain
My bent body mocks their torturing pain
Thy Father drew his Sword in the North
With his thousands strong he marched forth
Thy Brother has armdarmed himself in Steel13

To avenge the wrongs thy Children feel There is possibly an overwrite in "wrongs"; the "r" may have been written over another (illegible) letter. Neither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1311) nor Erdman (page 860n) notes this emendation.
But vain the Sword & vain the Bow
They never can work Wars overthrow
The Hermits Prayer & the Widows Tear
Alone can free the World from fear
For a Tear is an Intellectual Thing
And a Sigh is the Sword of an Angel King
And the bitter groan of the Martyrs woe
Is an Arrow from the Almighties Bow
The hand of Vengeance found the Bed
To which the Purple Tyrant fled
The iron hand crushdcrushed the Tyrants head Erdman (page 490) reads "head" as "Head".
And became a Tyrant in his Stead
Auguries of Innocence
To see a World in a Grain of Sand
And a Heaven in a Wild Flower
Hold Infinity in the palm of your hand
And Eternity in an hour
A Robin Red breast in a Cage
Puts all Heaven in a Rage
A Dove house filldfilled with Doves & Pigeons
14 Shudders Hell thro all its regions
A dog starvdstarved at his Masters Gate
Predicts the ruin of the State
A Horse misusdmisused upon the Road
Calls to Heaven for Human blood
Each outcry of the hunted Hare
A fibre from the Brain does tear
A Skylark wounded in the wing Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1312) reads "Skylark" as "sky lark".
A Cherubim does cease to sing
The Game Cock clipdclipped & armdarmed for fight
Does the Rising Sun affrightBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1733n) suggests that "rising" was mended to "Rising".
Every Wolfs & Lions howl
Raises from Hell a Human Soul
The wild deer wandringwandering here & there
Keeps the Human Soul from Care
The Lamb misusdmisused breeds Public strife Erdman (page 490) reads "strife" as "Strife".
And yet forgives the Butchers Knife
The Bat that flits at close of Eve
Has left the Brain that wont Believe
The Owl atthat calls upon the Night Neither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1312) nor Erdman (page 860n) notes this emendation.
Speaks the Unbelievers fright
He who shall hurt the little Wren
Shall never be belovdbeloved by Men

objnote.p: Lines 7-8 from "The Auguries of Innocence" appear in slightly revised form in "The Keys," Plate 19 in For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 1313n).

lg.l: He who the Ox to wrath has movdmoved15
Shall never be by Woman lovdloved
The wanton Boy that kills the Fly
Shall feel the Spiders enmity
He who torments the Chafers sprite
Weaves a Bower in endless Night
The CatterpillerCaterpillar on the Leaf Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1313) reads "Catterpiller" as "Caterpiller".
Repeats to thee thy Mothers grief
Kill not the Moth nor Butterfly
For the Last JudgmentJudgement draweth nigh
He who shall train the Horse to War
Shall never pass the Polar Bar
The Beggers Dog & Widows Cat
Feed them & thou wilt grow fat
The Gnat that sings his Summers song
Poison gets from Slanders tongue
The poison of the Shnake & Newt Neither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1313) nor Erdman (page 860n) notes this emendation.
Is the sweat of Envys Foot
The Poison of the Honey Bee
Is the Artists Jealousy
The Princes Robes & Beggars Rags
Are Toadstools on the Misers Bags Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1313) does not note this alteration; Erdman (page 860n) reads the deletion as "in".
A Truth thats told with bad intent
Beats all the Lies you can invent

objnote.p: According to Bentley, an erased printed word in the left margin (on line 26) is the catchword "With" from page 20 of Hayley's Designs to a Series of Ballads (1802), for which Blake made engravings. The abandoned *Ballads* sheets were cut to remove Hayley's text (and the "1802" watermark), leaving the wide inner margins for Blake's own poems Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1733n).

lg.l: 16 It is right it should be so
Man was made for Joy & Woe
And when this we rightly know Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1313) reads "know" as "Know".
Thro the World we safely go
Joy & Woe are woven fine
A Clothing for the soul divine
Under every grief & pine
Runs a joy with silken twine
The Babe is more than Swadling Bands Erdman (page 491) reads "Swadling" as "swadling".
Throughout all these Human Lands
Tools were made & Born were hands
Every Farmer Understands
Every Tear from Every Eye
Becomes a Babe in Eternity
And returndreturned to its own delight
The Bleat the Bark Bellow & Roar
Are Waves that Beat on Heavens Shore
The Babe that weeps the Rod beneath
Writes Revenge in realms of DeathBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1314) reads "Death" as "death".
The Beggars Rags fluttering in Air
Does to Rags the Heavens tear
The Soldier armed with Sword & Gun
Palsied strikes the Summers Sun

The poor MansMan's Farthing is worth more According to Bentley, an erased printed word in the left margin is the catchword "With" from page 20 of Hayley's *Designs to a Series of Ballads* (1802), for which Blake made engravings. The abandoned *Ballads* sheets were cut to remove Hayley's text (and the "1802" watermark), leaving the wide inner margins for Blake's own poems.
Than all the Gold on Africs Shore

objnote.p: When the manuscript was bound in 1866, the edges were gilt and trimmed, affecting the descender of a letter in the the last line.

lg.l: One Mite wrung from the LabrersLaborersLabourers hands 17
Shall buy & sell the Misers Lands
Or if protected from on high
Does that whole Nation sell & buy
He who mocks the Infants Faith
Shall be mock'dmocked in Age & Death
He who shall teach the Child to Doubt
The rotting Grave shall neernever get out
He who respects the Infants faith
Triumphs over Hell & Death
The Childs Toys & the Old MansMan's Reasons
Are the Fruits of the Two seasons
The Questioner who sits so sly
Shall never know how to ReplyBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1314) reads "know" as "Know".
He who replies to words of Doubt
Doth put the Light of Knowledge out
The Strongest Poison ever known
Came from Caesars Laurel Crown
Nought can deform the Human Race
Like to the ArmoursArmors iron brace
When Gold & Gems adorn the Plow
To peaceful Arts shall Envy Bow
A Riddle or the Crickets Cry
Is to Doubt a fit Reply
The Emmets Inch & Eagles Mile
Make Lame Philosophy to smile

objnote.p: When the manuscript was bound in 1866, the edges were gilt and trimmed, affecting the tops of a few letters in the first line.

lg.l: 18 He who Doubts from what he sees
Will neernever Believe do what you Please
If the Sun & Moon should Doubt
Theyd immediately Go out
To be in a Passion you Good may Do
But no Good if a Passion is in you
The Whore & Gambler by the State
LicencdLicensed build that Nations Fate
The Harlots cry from Street to Street
Shall weave Old Englands winding Sheet
The wWinners Shout the Losers Curse Erdman (page 890n) does not note this emendation.
Dance before dead Englands Hearse Neither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1315) nor Erdman (page 890n) note this emendation.
eEvery Night & every MornThe initial letters in lines 13 through 15 have been emended to capital letters. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1315) does not note these alterations.
sSome to Misery are Born
EEvery Morn & every Night
Some are Born to sweet delight In lines 16 through 18, the initial word "Some" may have been mended; Erdman (page 860n) suggests changes in capitalization.
Some are Born to sweet delight
Some are Born to Endless Night
TWe are led to Believe a Lie Neither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1315) nor Erdman (page 890n) notes this emendation.
When we see With not Thro the Eye Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1315n) notes that this deletion is in brown ink, while the rest of the line is in black ink.

TWhich was Born in a Night to perish in a Night Like lines 13 through 15 above, the initial letters of lines 21 through 22 have been emended to capital letters. Neither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1315) nor Erdman (page 890n) notes these alterations.
TWhen the Soul Slept in Beams of Light
God Appears & God is Light
To those poor Souls who dwell in Night
But does a Human Form Display
To those who Dwell in Realms of day

desc.objtitle: Long John Brown & Little Mary Bell, Object 19 (Bentley 126.19)

l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1315n) notes that while the manuscript is written in black ink, "Little" in inserted over a caret in grey, as are all the emendations in lines 3 through 8. While these alterations to the first stanza of the poem may seem lighter, this variation is more likely due to a pen that contained less (or diluted) ink. There does not appear to be a caret in the manuscript.

lg.l: Long John Brown & Mary Bell 19 The "M" in "Mary" may have been written over another illegible letter.
Pretty Mary Bell had a Fairy in a Nut
Young John Brown had the Devil in his Gut
Young John Brown lovdlovedPretty Mary Bell
And the Fairy drew the Devil into the Nut-shell
Her Fairy skipdskipped out & her Fairy SkipdSkipped inBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1316) reads "skipd ... Skipd" as "Skipd ... skipd", while Erdman (page 496) reads "skipd ... skipd".
He laughdlaughed at the Devil saying Love is a Sin The "y" in "Saying" may have been mended.
The Devil he raged & the devil he was wroth Both Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1316) and Erdman (page 496) read the second "devil" as "Devil".
And the Devil enterdentered into the Young MansMan's broth
He was soon in the Gut of the loving Young Swain
For John eat & drank to drive away LovesLove's pain
But all he could do he grew thinner & thinner
Tho he eat & drank as much as ten Men for his dinner
Some said he had a Wolf in his stomach day & night
Some said he had the Devil & they guessdguessed right
The fairy skipdskipped about in his Glory Joy & Pride
And he laughdlaughed at the Devil till poor John Brown died
Then the Fairy skipdskipped out of the old Nut shell
And woe & alack for Pretty Mary Bell
For the TDevil crept in when The Fairy skipdskipped outNeither Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1316) nor Erdman (page 496) notes this emendation.
And there goes Miss Bell with her fusty old Nut
William Bond
I wonder whether the Girls are mad Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1316) reads "mad" as "Mad".
And I wonder whether they mean to kill Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1316) reads "kill" as "Kill".
And I wonder if William Bond will die
For assuredly he is very ill
He went to Church in a May morning
Attended by Fairies one two & three
But the Angels of Providence drove them away
And he returndreturned home in Misery
He went not out to the Field nor Fold
He went not out to the Village nor Town
But he came home in a black black cloud
And took to his Bed & there lay down
And an Angel of Providence at his Feet
And an Angel of Providence at his Head
And in the midst a Black Black Cloud
And in the midst the Sick Man on his Bed
And on his Right hand was Mary Green
And on his Left hand was his Sister Jane
And their tears fell thro the black black Cloud
To drive away the sick mansman's pain

objnote.p: Line 8 appears in "The Everlasting Gospel," part d, in Blake's Notebook and in "To Tirzah," Plate 52 in Songs of Innocence and of Experience (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 1317n).

lg.l: OWilliam if thou dost another Love21 Erdman (page 860n) suggests that the "O" at the beginning of the line was an addition to the original "William".
Dost another Love better than poor Mary
Go & take that other to be thy Wife
And Mary Green shall her Servant be
Yes Mary I do another Love
Another I Love far better than thee
And Another I will have for my Wife
Then what have I to do with thee
For thou art Melancholy Pale
And on thy Head is the cold Moons shine
But she is ruddy & bright as day
And the sun beams dazzle from her eyneeyes
Mary trembled & Mary chilldchilled
And Mary fell down on the right hand floor
That William Bond & his Sister Jane
Scarce could recover Mary more
When Mary woke & found her Laid
On the Right hand of her William dear
On the Right hand of his loved Bed
And saw her William Bond so near
The Fairies that fled from William Bond
Danced around her Shining Head
They danced over the Pillow white
And the Angels of Providence left the Bed
I thought Love livdlived in the hot sun Shine
But O he lives in the Moony light
I thought to find Love in the heat of day
But sweet Love is the Comforter of Night
Seek Love in the Pity of others Woe
In the gentle relief of anothers care
In the darkness of night & the winterswinter's snow
In the naked & outcast Seek Love There Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1318) reads "There" as "there".
